message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of RBC casts and dysmorphic features in the urine suggests glomerular involvement. Options B, C, and D suggest different types of glomerulonephritis, but the presence of immune complexes in the urine supports subepithelial immune complex deposition as the most likely cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of proteinuria, hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, and RBC casts suggest glomerular injury. Among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition is associated with glomerulonephritis and can result in these findings. Antibodies against type IV collagen are associated with Alport syndrome, which typically presents with hematuria and proteinuria in young boys but without edema. Defective circulating IgA antibodies are associated with IgA nephropathy, which typically presents with hematuria and proteinuria but without edema. Inflammation of small-sized blood vessels may be a feature of vasculitis, but this is not suggested by the clinical presentation and laboratory findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the presence of dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts in the urine suggest glomerulonephritis. Among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition is the most likely cause of these findings. Antibodies against type IV collagen cause thin basement membrane disease, defective circulating IgA antibodies cause IgA nephropathy, and inflammation of small-sized blood vessels cause vasculitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest glomerulonephritis. Among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition is the most likely cause, as evidenced by the presence of RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs in the urine analysis. Antibodies against type IV collagen and defective circulating IgA antibodies are associated with other forms of glomerulonephritis, while inflammation of small-sized blood vessels is associated with vasculitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest glomerulonephritis. The presence of RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs with 2+ blood and 2+ protein in urine strongly support the diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition is the most likely cause of glomerulonephritis. Antibodies against type IV collagen are associated with Alport syndrome, which usually presents in childhood and is inherited. Defective circulating IgA antibodies cause IgA nephropathy, which is an immune disorder that affects the kidneys. Inflammation of small-sized blood vessels causes vasculitis, which can also cause glomerulonephritis but is not the most likely cause in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of nephrotic syndrome and the presence of RBC casts and dysmorphic features in the urine suggests glomerular involvement. Among the options, only subepithelial immune complex deposition is associated with glomerular involvement and the presentation of nephrotic syndrome with hematuria. Antibodies against type IV collagen are associated with Goodpasture syndrome which presents as pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis. Defective circulating IgA antibodies are associated with IgA nephropathy which presents as recurrent episodes of hematuria and proteinuria. Inflammation of small-sized blood vessels is associated with autoimmune vasculitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a skin infection four weeks ago and presents with periorbital and pretibial edema, as well as dysmorphic RBC casts and subnephrotic proteinuria. These findings suggest a glomerular disease, and among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition is the most likely cause, which is commonly seen in post-infectious glomerulonephritis. Antibodies against type IV collagen are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, defective circulating IgA antibodies are seen in IgA nephropathy, and inflammation of small-sized blood vessels is seen in ANCA-associated vasculitis, which do not fit the clinical picture of this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with glomerulonephritis, and among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition is the most likely cause. Antibodies against type IV collagen are associated with Goodpasture syndrome, defective circulating IgA antibodies are associated with IgA nephropathy, and inflammation of small-sized blood vessels is associated with vasculitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, laboratory findings, and presence of RBC casts suggest glomerulonephritis. Among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition is the most likely cause based on the presence of dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts, which suggest a renal origin of hematuria. Antibodies against type IV collagen is associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which usually presents with pulmonary and renal symptoms. Defective circulating IgA antibodies is associated with IgA nephropathy, which usually presents with hematuria and proteinuria. Inflammation of small-sized blood vessels is associated with vasculitis, which can cause glomerulonephritis but typically presents with other systemic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts in the urine suggests glomerulonephritis. Among the options, subepithelial immune complex deposition best fits the symptoms and laboratory findings. Antibodies against type IV collagen are seen in Alport syndrome, which is less likely since the patient’s brother has steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome rather than Alport syndrome. Defective circulating IgA antibodies are seen in IgA nephropathy, but this does not explain the dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts. Inflammation of small-sized blood vessels suggests vasculitis, which is not supported by the patient’s presentation.
